awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Social dynamics and fitness in a complex primate society
awd_abstract_narration:
Social species live in groups that vary dramatically in size. For any species, the maximum group size represents a breaking point, where the costs of group-living outweigh the benefits. Yet, most research on the social dynamics of groups has focused on societies with one level of social organization. These "single-level societies" are bound to one compromise solution when faced with competing selective pressures - grow in size to protect against predation? Or, shrink in size to alleviate feeding competition? Yet, a few societies have solved this group-size conundrum through the evolution of "multi-level societies" - comprising many modular core groups where individuals within the core group are consistent while the associations between core groups can quickly change. This research will explore how individuals transitioned from single- to multi-level societies by investigating the multilevel society of a wild primate, the gelada. This project asks two questions that each focus on a hallmark of gelada society. First, what permanently splits groups apart? And, second, what keeps groups together - forming the higher levels? This project has previously demonstrated that geladas have an unusually high tolerance for strangers. Identifying the mechanisms behind this remarkable tolerance could help us understand the evolution of another species' tolerance for strangers - humans. The directors of this project will continue a long-standing tradition of national and international STEM outreach (http://geladaresearch.org/db) and  significant time investment into conservation efforts in Ethiopia through Save the Simiens, a 501(c)(3) non-profit they created dedicated to protecting the wildlife of the Simien Mountains National Park of Ethiopia where the research takes place. This project is co-funded by the Animal Behavior Program in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Biological Anthropology Program in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences.

The objective of this research is to identify how individual interactions lead to the higher-order structure of multi-level societies by harnessing long-term data on multiple core groups of wild geladas (Theropithecus gelada), an easy-to-observe primate with a multilevel society. Specifically, this project will identify: (1) what causes core groups to split up (i.e., fission into two or more core groups) and (2) what causes multiple core groups to remain together (i.e., maintain higher-level cohesion). This research will investigate the fitness consequences of behaviors that produce a multi-level society and examine the mechanistic processes by which group structure may emerge from individual interactions. To understand why groups fission, it is necessary to track network dynamics to examine female social networks before and after a fission to identify the changes in social relationships that may predict an impending fission. To understand higher-level cohesion, this research will use GPS collars to track simultaneous movement across core groups that have (and have not) undergone fission. Thus, these results will identify the "decay" in association patterns across time. By identifying the origin of two key features of multilevel societies - small core groups and cohesion among those groups - this research will uncover not just why gelada units fission but how they fission; and this evolutionary pathway can then be tested in other taxa.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most social animals live in cohesive groups that remain together across time. By contrast, multi-level societies are characterized by nested groups-within-groups that temporarily fission and fuse as necessary across time. Such societies occur in only a handful of species, including humans. Multi-level societies are an ideal solution to the problems of sociality; individuals receive the benefits of a large group (maximizing predator protection) as well as a small group (minimizing competition for food). Notably, species with multi-level societies show a clear association with complex cognition. Thus, one hypothesis for the evolution of multi-level societies is that navigating the complex problems of sociality might be cognitively challenging. Our motivation was to ask why some species are able to create and sustain multi-level societies, while others are not. We address this question with research on one of the classic examples of a multi-level society: wild geladas (Theropithecus gelada) living in Ethiopia.

Gelada society has three levels: (1) core units, comprising one dominant male, 1-12 related females, their offspring, and 0-3 subordinate males; (2) bands, comprising 2-10 core units that travel together, and (3) the community, comprising all bands that live in an area. Gelada communities are among the largest naturally occurring groups of primates in the world. We break down multi-level societies into two defining characteristics that differ from the more-common “single-level” societies. First, compared to single-level societies, multi-level societies have unusually small core social units. Second, while single-level societies only interact with other groups to fight, multi-level societies have consistent (friendly) assemblages of core units. In well-studied single-level societies, fissions of the largest groups are permanent, producing two groups that go their separate ways, while in multi-level societies even the products of permanent core unit fissions remain together for years. The questions, therefore, are: What causes gelada groups to break into small core units? And, What causes gelada core units to maintain these higher social levels?

What causes small core units? To answer this, we gathered data on reproduction and mortality to demonstrate the costs and benefits to living in small vs large units. We map this onto our 15-year history on permanent fissions and fusions of core units. First, we found that only the largest units fission; and only the smallest units fuse. Second, we found a “Goldilock’s effect” where the optimally sized unit was mid-sized, effectively minimizing the costs of infanticide (highest in largest units) and maximizing the benefits of predator protection (also highest in largest units). These mid-sized units had the lowest adult mortality, the highest fertility rates, and the lowest infanticide. Thus, we suggest there is selection against individuals in the largest and smallest units that prompts core units to fission and fuse, respectively.

What causes higher social levels? To answer this, we use two approaches - one evolutionary, one mechanistic. For the evolutionary approach, we use socioecological theory to support the benefits of living in larger groups. Geladas live in open grasslands, making them vulnerable to predators (who kill them) and bachelor males (who steal their females). Staying in close proximity to hundreds of individuals provides “selfish-herd benefits” reducing an individual’s risk of being the target of a dangerous animal. Moreover, geladas feed on a dispersed food resource (grass), so there is less food competition even when in a group comprising hundreds of geladas. For the mechanistic approach, we are using movement data (GPS data on groups and individuals) to track permanent core unit fissions. We are still analyzing these data, but we expect that recently-fissioned-units remain in closer association than distantly-fissioned-units. Thus, rather than reflecting some active process of cohesion, the higher levels of gelada society simply reflect the slow degradation of cognitive and geographical association in an otherwise expanding population. 

To place this research in a comparative context, we then relate results to our research in single-level societies (chacma baboons and capuchins). We are struck by two things. First, geladas are extremely tolerant of the close proximity of complete strangers. In the less-fluid societies of chacmas and capuchins, this would be an entirely threatening scenario resulting in aggression. How geladas achieve this tolerance is highly relevant for understand human evolution, since humans are one of the only other primates who tolerate complete strangers. Second, geladas are relatively uncooperative. They only form alliances within core units during aggressive encounters with neighbors. There is no cooperation at the higher levels. This is in sharp contrast with their “social tolerance” which lends support to the idea that parochial altruism can shape cooperation. Capuchins, in particular, are extremely cooperative within their groups. It may be that the threat of extra-group individuals drives this social cohesion. As we work to understand how between-group competition shapes within-group cooperation, we can gain a better understanding of how humans balance cooperation within groups, competition across groups, and a remarkable tolerance of strangers.
